chapter.htmlHeader: How do I assess someone with tinnitus?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Ask about:
    • The onset, quality, duration, and frequency of the tinnitus.
    • The features of tinnitus:
      • Unilateral or bilateral.
      • Continuous or episodic.
      • Pulsatile, and, if so, if it is in time with the person's heart.
      • Associated with hearing loss.
    • Additional symptoms such as dizziness, vertigo, balance problems, jaw pain or clicking, facial weakness, or sensitivity to loud noises.
    • Any relieving or exacerbating factors (for example background noise, stress, lack of sleep, position).
    • The impact of tinnitus — consider using the Tinnitus Functional Index. If questionnaires cannot be used (for example, because of language issues or cognitive impairment) consider using a visual analogue scale.
      • Discuss with the person, and their family members or carers if appropriate, how the condition affects their quality of life (home, social, leisure, work).
      • Consider using the Insomnia Severity Index and discuss the results with the person. 
      • Be alert to the impact of tinnitus on mental health — consider using the tinnitus questionnaire (TQ) or the mini-TQ. If there are concerns about depression or anxiety carry out an appropriate mental health assessment. For more information, see the CKS topics on Depression and Generalized anxiety disorder. 
    • Current medications, including over-the-counter and herbal remedies.
    • History of significant noise exposure from occupational or recreational activities.
    • Previous history of ear surgery, infections or injury, or head trauma.
    • Previous history of cardiovascular or metabolic diseases.
  • Determine if the tinnitus is objective or subjective.
    • Objective tinnitus usually has a clicking or pulsatile character and can also be heard by the clinician. Auscultate the peri-auricular area and over the temporal bone, orbit, and vascular structures of the neck. Carotid bruits, jugular venous hum, arteriovenous malformation thrill, or myoclonic clicks may be heard.
    • Subjective tinnitus is not audible with a stethoscope by the examiner.
  • Examine the ears, nose, and throat.
    • Use an auriscope to detect disorders affecting the middle and outer ear (for example wax, otitis externa, otitis media with effusion, perforation of the tympanic membrane, and cholesteatoma).
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Earwax, Otitis externa, and Otitis media with effusion.
    • Weber and Rinne tuning fork tests can be used to identify sensorineural or conductive hearing loss.
    • Observation of the palate may reveal palatal myoclonus.
  • Examine the jaw for any snapping or clicking indicative of temporomandibular joint dysfunction. For more information see the CKS topic on Temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
  • Perform a neurological assessment, including assessing the cranial nerves.
  • Look for clinical features of anaemia, thyroid disease, hyperlipidaemia, and diabetes and consider checking:
    • Random or fasting blood glucose.
    • Thyroid function.
    • Full blood count.
    • Lipid levels.
  • If tinnitus is pulsatile, examine the head and neck, check the person's blood pressure, and examine the cardiovascular system for heart murmurs, carotid or temporal artery bruits, and vascular sounds.
  • For more information on features of tinnitus and associated factors suggesting an underlying diagnosis, see the sections on Determining the cause of subjective tinnitus and Determining the cause of objective tinnitus.

Determining the cause of objective tinnitus

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Tinnitus: assessment and management [NICE, 2020a], European guidelines [AWMF, 2015], US guidelines [Tunkel, 2014; Yew, 2014], expert opinion from the British Tinnitus Association [British Tinnitus Association, 2012; British Tinnitus Association, 2017], and review articles [Ruppert, 2012; Baguley, 2013; Meehan and Nogueira, 2014; Zimmerman, 2014; Truscott, 2016; BMJ Best Practice, 2017].

  • NICE recommends considering the use of questionnaires to assess tinnitus as they enable the development of a management plan targeted to the individual’s needs. However, while it found no evidence that evaluated the clinical effectiveness of questionnaires to assess tinnitus, the committee noted that they were a crucial part of the management pathway [NICE, 2020b]. 
  • The American Academy of Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Foundation Clinical Practice Guideline on Tinnitus recommends, based on observational studies, that a targeted history and examination when a person with tinnitus initially presents can allow identification of conditions that may be managed to relieve tinnitus [Tunkel, 2014]. A simple approach to assessing a person with tinnitus can also detect more serious diagnoses such as Meniere's disease or acoustic neuroma [Yew, 2014].
  • Most people with tinnitus will not have relevant positive physical findings, but the history and examination can help to determine if the tinnitus has a treatable cause and ascertain its effect on the person and their family [Baguley, 2013; Tunkel, 2014].
  • Diagnostic testing is limited in a primary care setting [Ruppert, 2012]. Some people will require further investigation for their tinnitus [Yew, 2014]. This is usually arranged in secondary care following referral.
  • The American Academy of Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Foundation recommends distinguishing people with bothersome tinnitus from those with non-bothersome tinnitus to allow an appropriate decision to be made on treatment based on the relative benefits and harms [Tunkel, 2014]. An assessment of the impact on quality of life is important because the location and severity of tinnitus do not always correlate with the distress reported by the patient [Meehan and Nogueira, 2014].
